39 EXTD
Exhaust system temperature determination

EXTD, EXTD General
39.1 EXTD General
� General Information
EXTD (EXhaust system Temperature Determination) is the aggregate where all necessary temperatures in the
exhaust line are determined. These temperatures are used for different purposes in different other functionali-
ties:
1. Component overheating prevention: Turbine and Catalyst overheating prevention
2. Lambda sensor heater management
3. Catalyst ef?ciency diagnosis
Additionally EXTD is responsible for the dew point detection (or dew point passed detection) which is used for
the full activation of the lambda sensor heater.
In general there are two ways to determine the temperatures in the exhaust line:
1. Measurement of the exhaust gas temperature
2. Model of the exhaust temperature dependent on the engine operating conditions
The model is always necessary to have a back up information in case of sensor damage and the sensor
damage has also to be detected.
So EXTD can be split up in 4 parts:
1. Exhaust gas temperature sensor acquisition
2. Exhaust gas temperature sensor diagnosis
3. Exhaust gas temperature model
4. Dew point detection
� Architecture Overview
39.1.1 Exhaust gas temperature sensor acquisition
Three speci?cations belong to this part:
EXTD infrastructure requirement speci?cation (IRS):
Speci?es all information concerning the hardware of the ECU and how often the sensor information is updated.
If no sensor is available in the system (NC_TEG_SENS_TYP = No Sensor) this speci?cation is skipped.
Exhaust gas temperature sensors (Appl. Inc.):
Project speci?c part to inhibit the sensor acquisition for different cases e.g.: If the sensor is only available for
certain con?gurations: Turbo / non Turbo; US market / European market. If no sensor is available in the system
(NC_TEG_SENS_TYP = No Sensor) this speci?cation is skipped.
Exhaust gas temperature sensors:
Deals with the sensor information acquisition which can be the raw value of the ADC converter or a PWM
value in case of a sensor type with external evaluation control unit which communicated with the ECU by
PWM information. Conversion of the raw value in a "raw" exhaust gas temperature and ?ltering of this "raw"
exhaust gas temperature. If no sensor is available in the system (NC_TEG_SENS_TYP = No Sensor) TEG_MES is
initialized by zero within this speci?cation.
39.1.2 Exhaust gas temperature sensor diagnosis
This part consists out of two speci?cations:
Exhaust gas temperature sensor diagnosis (Appl. Inc.):
Project speci?c part where the conditions for the activation of the different diagnosis are speci?ed and also
the anti bounce behaviour of the different diagnosis are speci?ed. If no sensor is available in the system
(NC_TEG_SENS_TYP = No Sensor) this speci?cation is skipped.
Exhaust gas temperature sensor diagnosis:
4 different types of diagnosis are carried out here: electrical diagnosis, cold start diagnosis, increment diagnosis

EXTD, EXTD General
and gradient diagnosis. If no sensor is available in the system (NC_TEG_SENS_TYP = No Sensor) the global error
?ag LV_ERR_TEG_MES is initialized by zero.
39.1.3 Exhaust gas temperature model
This part is the most important and also the biggest part of EXTD with the following 7 speci?cations:
Exhaust gas temperature model (Appl. Inc.):
In this project speci?c part almost all inputs of the exhaust gas temperature model are generated out of the
available system information. E.g.: The engine speed for the exhaust gas temperature model N_TEG is gener-
ated out of the system variable N. This is done to deal with different customer request (e.g.: to have a ?ltered
engine speed as input for the exhaust gas temperature model). Additionally several customer speci?c correc-
tions (e.g.: TEG_ENG_OUT_ADD_CUS) for different purposes (e.g.: VVL and MPLH corrections) can be generated
here.
Exhaust gas temperature model:
This module is the manager of the exhaust gas temperature model. All component models (Engine out- / Tube-
/ Turbine- and Catalyst exhaust gas temperature model) are coordinated here. This means the manager calls
the different component models in the right order with the correct update rate and writes the result calculated
in the component model in the right position of the arrays (TEG_DYN_MDL, TEG, LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL...). It
handles also at which position the sensor information is used instead of the model based value. There is
only one calibration data in the speci?cation LC_TEG_MDL_SENS_ENA which has to be set to one if the sensor
information shall be used (if no sensor error detected). So for calibration this speci?cation is not important.
Engine out exhaust gas temperature model:
In this module all engine operating point dependencies (e.g.: engine speed, load, ignition angle ...) are used to
determine the ?rst temperature which is effective engine out exhaust gas temperature. Additional the engine
out exhaust gas humidity is determined here.
Tube exhaust gas temperature model:
This model part is used to simulate the cooling down of the exhaust gas and the in?uence on the dynamic of
the exhaust gas temperature by the in?uence of the heat capacity of an exhaust pipe like the exhaust manifold
and by the external conditions like ambient temperature and vehicle speed.
Turbine exhaust gas temperature model:
This model part is used to simulate the cooling down of the exhaust gas due to the turbine power and the
in?uence on the dynamic of the exhaust gas temperature by the in?uence of the heat capacity of the turbine
housing and by the external conditions like ambient temperature and vehicle speed.
Catalyst exhaust gas temperature model:
This model part is used to simulate the catalyst temperature and it?s dynamic. Therefore the exothermic
reactions are considered to calculate the increased temperature in the catalyst and also ambient temperature
and vehicle speed are again used to calculate the exhaust gas temperature downstream catalyst.
EXTD Output selection
At the end of the calculation all exhaust gas temperatures are available in the array TEG[NC_NR_TEG_MDL] but
the output of the aggregate are values with a certain naming (e.g.: TEG_DYN_UP_CAT). For each value with a
certain naming a value out of TEG has to be selected. This mapping is done in this module.
39.1.4 Dew point detection
The dew point detection is a project speci?c speci?cation because there are several strategies for this func-
tionality. All information?s out of the exhaust gas temperature model, like modelled tube wall temperatures
and the internal dew point ?ags for each position in the exhaust line LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL[NC_NR_TEG_MDL],
can be used to determine the "dew point passed ?ag" LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_UP/DOWN for the upstream and
downstream sensor. But also mass air ?ow integral can be used to set the dew point ?ag. Of course also
combinations out of these information?s are possible.

But also mass air ?ow integral can be used to set the dew point ?ag. Of course also
combinations out of these information?s are possible.

PRS_IM / PUT_POW_CHA_MIN < (C_FAC_PRS_IM_POW_CHA_MIN - C_FAC_PRS_IM_POW_
CHA_MIN_HYS)
Then
POW_CBK_TEG_TUR_OFS = IP_POW_CBK_TEG_TUR_OFS (N_TEG, MEF_CBK_TEG)
Endif
If
LV_PUC =1
Then
POW_CBK_TEG_TUR_PUC = IP_POW_CBK_TEG_TUR_PUC (T_PUC)
Else
POW_CBK_TEG_TUR_PUC = 0
Endif
If
LC_SWI_POW_CBK_TEG_TUR = 0
Then
POW_CBK_TEG_TUR [NC_CBK_EX_NR] = POW_CHA [NC_NR_TCHA] + POW_CBK_TEG_TUR_
OFS + POW_CBK_TEG_TUR_PUC
Else
POW_CBK_TEG_TUR [NC_CBK_EX_NR] = POW_CHA_SP + POW_CBK_TEG_TUR_OFS + POW_
CBK_TEG_TUR_PUC
Endif

� General Information
The manager of the exhaust gas temperature model is the module which coordinates the different component
models. Dependent on the con?guration the manager calls the different component models (Engine out,
Tube, Catalyst, Turbine model) in the con?gured order and update rate. The results of the different component
models are written back by the action "ACTION_EXTD_Data2Manag" into the values:
TEG_DYN_MDL
TEG_STAT_MDL
HUM_EX_GAS_MDL
LV_DEW_TEMP_DEW_MDL

Figure 39.6.1:
If a sensor value is available and no sensor error is detected the output TEG, which is input for the next model,
is equal to the measured value (TEG_MES) if the corresponding LC_TEG_MDL_SENS_ENA[NC_NR_TEG_SENS] is
set to one. On the other hand if an error is detected or no sensor is available or the LC_TEG_MDL_SENS_ENA
is equal zero TEG[i] is equal to TEG_DYN_MDL[i].
All dynamic exhaust gas temperatures are initializied with the component temperature upstream its position.
The component temperature itselfe is initializied in the component model by using the stored temperature at
engine shut down weighted by a cooling down factor dependent on the engine off duration time T_ES. Due to
the fact that the engine out model has no component temperature TCO is used as component temperature.
In the given example the exhaust gas temperatures initialized as following:
TEG[1] = TEG_DYN_MDL[1] = TCO
TEG[2] = TEG_DYN_MDL[2] = TEMP_TUBE[1]
TEG[3] = TEG_DYN_MDL[2] = TEMP_TUR[1]
TEG[4] = TEG_DYN_MDL[2] = TEMP_TUBE[2]
TEG[5] = TEG_DYN_MDL[1] = TEMP_CAT[1]
The steady state temperatures TEG_STAT_MDL, the humidities HUM_EX_GAS_MDL and the dewpoint ?ags of
the model LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL are all initialized with zero.

39.6.2 Exhaust gas temperature model manager during Engine Run
39.6.2.1 Exhaust gas temperature model manager
This function manages calculation order of the component temperature models. This is done by a modulo
operation dependent on the EXTD con?guration.
After the calculation of the component model the manager decides whether a sensor information can be used
instead of the modeled value.
39.6.2.1.1 Calculation temperature validation ?ag and triggers
At very quick start some measured signals are not available before engine start. Calculation validation ?ag
ensure that the calculation of temperatures during engine off are done using plausible inputs.
Trigger "operate_TEG_MDL_AD":
In case of not plausible T_ES or TAM and TCO, the temperatures calculated by the temperature model are not
correct. This trigger calls the same functionality which is called at 1s task (cooling down) for adaptation of the
temperatures. This call is generated only once short after engine start.
Trigger "operate_TEG_MDL":
This is the 10ms trigger for the manager of TEG models active at running engine.

39.6.3 Exhaust gas temperature model manager during engine stop
The calculation at engine off are not available when the cooling down for all three components is not bound,
means NC_COOL_ACT_TUBE/CAT/TUR are set to "0".
39.6.3.1 Cooling down manager
At engine off cooling down of the temperatures is active. After very long time the component and exhaust
gas temperatures are equal to the ambient temperature.
Trigger "opersate_TEG_MDL_ES":
This is regularly 1s task, active only if the temperature validation ?ag is set and the engine is off
Trigger "operate_TEG_MDL_AD":
This is one shot trigger at rising edge of the temperature validation ?ag for adaptation of the temperatures
Task "operate_TEG_MDL_ES2ERU":
Initialization of the temperatures at engine start. When the start was very short after reset with not plausible
input temperatures or engine off timer, then it is still possible to adapt the temperatures using "operate_TEG_
MDL_AD".

� General Information
This module is used to detect when the dew phase in the exhaust line is ?nished. This is necessary because
the lambda sensors can only be heated with full power if there is no risk of thermal shock due to water drops.

This is necessary because
the lambda sensors can only be heated with full power if there is no risk of thermal shock due to water drops.
Therefore for each sensor (up- /down stream / Auxillary of the catalyst; bank selective) a ?ag is set when the
dew phase is over:
LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_TMP[NC_CBK_EX_NR][NC_NR_LAMB_SENS]
k = NC_NR_LAMB_SENS - - no. of lambda sensors = 1...3
1 - - Only upstream sensor
2 - - Upstream and Downstream sensor
3 - - Upstream, Downstream and Auxillary sensor

EXTD, Dewpoint detection
Three conditions are checked to set these bits:
1. The condition is that the physical model of the water condensation in the exhaust gas temperature model
determines that there is no condensate in the exhaust lines upstream the sensor. Therefore the exhaust gas
temperature model delivers the ?ags LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL [NC_NR_TEG_MDL] for the different positions in the
exhaust line.
2. Additionally the model based wall temperatures are checked. The second condition is ful?lled if the corre-
sponding temperatures (TEMP_TUBE; TEMP_TUR) are above the calibratable thresholds:- IP_TEMP_THD_DEW_
LS_UP for the upstream sensor, IP_TEMP_THD_DEW_LS_DOWN for the downstream sensor, IP_TEMP_THD_
DEW_LS_AUX for the second downstream sensor(Auxillary)
3. In the case that the exhaust gas temperature model is not yet well calibrated a third condition can be
helpful to avoid sensor problems because it can be calibrated very fast. Therefore a weighted integral of
the mass air ?ow MAF_KGH_INT_DEW is calculated. The third condition is ful?lled if this integral is above
the following thresholds:- IP_MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_THD_LS_UP for the upstream sensor- IP_MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_
THD_LS_DOWN for the downstream sensor, IP_MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_THD _LS_AUX for the second downstream
sensor(Auxillary)
To set the ?ags LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_xx either condition 1. and 2. Are ful?lled or condition 3. Is ful?lled.
The module consists out of three major function parts:
1. Calculation of the mass air ?ow integral (update rate 1s)
2. Determination of the dew point (update rate 100ms)
3. Increment of the cold start counter (once at engine off)

39.7.2.3.2 Calculation of wall temperature at lambda sensors and internal dew point ?ags
39.7.2.3.2.1 FOR Loop:Temperatures calculation
39.7.2.3.2.1.1 Temperatures calculation
C_CTR_SEL_TUBE_LS_UP selects which tube wall temperature has to be used for the determination of the
second condition (wall temperature > threshold). In the same way as before there are selectors for each
sensor position (up-/downstream/Auxillary; bank selective).
LC_TEMP_TUR_DEW_LS_UP_ACT switches to use the turbine temperature to set upstream dew point.
For a downstream and auxillary sensor it is not considered to be after a turbine. Here LC_TEG_DEW_LS_ACT
is the switch to chose between exhaust gas temperature or tube wall temperature > threshold for setting
LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_xx. Selecting the right temperature is done via C_CTR_SEL_TEG_DEW_LS for exhaust gas
temperature and C_CTR_SEL_TUBE_LS for tube wall temperature depending on respective NC_NR_LAMB_SENS
value

39.7.2.3.4 FOR loop:Calculation of Flag indicating that dew point is passed at lambda sensor
Comparison of calculated thresholds with model temperature, check of ?ags LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL[NC_NR_
TEG_MDL] out of temperature model and MAF-Integral ?nished are the three main conditions to set the dew
point ?ags LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_TMP.
Additionally a certain time after start can be applied to inhibit dew point detection by C_T_AST_MIN_DEW_LS.
This time is affecting up,down-stream and auxillary dew point.
The basic threshold IP_MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_THD_LS[NC_NR_LAMB_SENS] can be incremented depending on
the CTR_COLD_ST by the factor ID_FAC_MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_THD[NC_NR_LAMB_SENS].

� Import actions:
ACTION_EXTD_Data2Manag(IN <PRM_HUM>, IN <PRM_LVDEW>, IN <PRM_TEGDYN>, IN <PRM_TEGSTAT>)
� General Information
The "engine out exhaust gas temperature model" is part of the complete exhaust gas temperature model. This
part contains the calculation of the effective engine out exhaust gas temperature depending on the engine
operating parameters and the engine out exhaust gas humidity.
This module handles the following dependencies of the engine out exhaust gas temperature:
- Engine operating point (Engine speed N_TEG and load MAF_TEG)
- Ignition angle dependency
- Lambda dependency
- Engine out temperature during PUC operation
For all other dependencies (VVT, EGR or MPL_XX, TCO, TIA, SAIR, FlexFuel)) it is possible to add project speci?c
corrections:
- TEG_ENG_OUT_ADD_CUS: additive correction on the engine out temperature
- FAC_TEG_ENG_OUT_CUS: multiplicative correction on the engine out temperature
- IGA_REF_TEG_ADD_CUS: additive correction on the reference ignition angle for the ignition angle dependency
of the engine out temperature

39.8.2 Formula section
Select values out of arrays:
This sub-function is just to select the corresponding cylinder bank selective values out of the arrays. The
variables lv_dew_thd_eng_out and teg_eng_out are sent to the arrays of the Manager via action ACTION_EXTD_
Data2Manag.
39.8.2.1 NC_PHY_MDL_ACT=2: Engine out exhaust gas humidity
In this function part the engine out exhaust gas humidity is determined. Therefore it is important to know, that
due to the combustion at lambda = 1, the engine produces almost constant amount of water (per kg exhaust
gas).
This value can be calibrated by calibration constant C_HUM_ENG_OUT.
Due to fact, that during cylinder shut off no combustion takes place, the water has to be reduced dependent
on the number of cylinder shut off on this cylinder bank.
That in this way calculated exhaust gas humidity has to be increased by the intake air humidity. Thereby it is
supposed that the relative humidity of the intake air is 100% because this is the worst case for the dew point
calculation. The intake air humidity is determined by the map IP_HUM_EX_GAS_MAX(TAM). Therefore TAM has
to be converted to TEG_AM to have the same resolution as the exhaust gas temperature.

ACTION_EXTD_Data2Manag(IN <PRM_HUM>, IN <PRM_LVDEW>, IN <PRM_TEGDYN>, IN <PRM_TEGSTAT>)
� General Information
The "tube exhaust gas temperature model" is part of the complete exhaust gas temperature model.
This is modeling of the behavior of a simple tube like the exhaust manifold or other tubes where the exhaust
gas is cooled down.
Therefore the outlet temperature TEG_DYN_DOWN_TUBE and the tube wall temperature TEMP_TUBE is mainly
calculated depending on: the ambient temperature TAM, the inlet exhaust gas temperature TEG_DYN_UP_
TUBE, the mass exhaust gas ?ow MEF_KGH_CBK_TEG.
The manager of the exhaust gas temperature model stores the result of the calculations in the according place
of array TEG.
Meaning of the suf?xes:
For exhaust bank speci?c variables (NC_CBK_EX_NR; TEG_MDL_CBK): "i"
For overall number of temperature models (NC_NR_TEG_MDL; TEG_MDL_INP): "t"
For number of tube temperature models (NC_NR_TUBE_MDL; CTR_TUBE_MDL): "p"

39.9.2 Initialization at transition from engine runs to engine stop
The variables except TEMP_TUBE_STOP are initialized with "0", the TEMP_TUBE_STOP is initialized with TEMP_
TUBE_CLC" to keep the information about tube wall temperature at engine stop.
39.9.3 Tube cooling at engine stop
39.9.3.1 Calculation of cooling of tube temperatures
The tube is cooling down if the engine and also the ECU is off. There are two different calculations for the
initialization. One for a valid and one for not valid or not existing engine off time.
In both cases a factor is determined which represents the cooling down progress. If the factor is equal to "1"
the tube cooling down is not modeled and its temperature is equal to the last temperature stored in the non
volatile memory. If the factor is zero, TEMP_TUBE is equal to the ambient temperature TAM.

- Filtering of the calculated exhaust gas temperature downstream tube

Figure 39.9.22:
39.9.4.6.2.4.2 Dew point calculations
The dew point calculation starts with the determination of the maximum of the humidity of the exhaust gas
downstream the tube.
In the next step the internal dew point ?ag is calculated. When this ?ag is set, no dew point calculation is active
and the downstream exhaust gas humidity is equal to the upstream humidity.
39.9.4.6.2.4.2.1 Calculation of Internal ?ag for Dew Point
To set internal dew point ?ag following conditions have to be ful?lled:
- There is no condensation water in the tube
- The exhaust gas temperature is high enough to transfer the incoming water

EXTD, Catalyst exhaust gas temperature model
� Import actions:
ACTION_EXTD_Data2Manag(IN <PRM_HUM>, IN <PRM_LVDEW>, IN <PRM_TEGDYN>, IN <PRM_TEGSTAT>)
� General Information
General information:
The "catalyst exhaust gas temperature model" is part of the complete exhaust gas temperature model. This
part models the behavior of a catalyst where the exhaust gas is heated up in the ?rst part of the catalyst by
the exothermic reaction and cooled down in the second part. Therefore the model is also split up into two
parts.
The catalyst monolith temperature TEMP_CAT is calculated in the ?st part and the outlet exhaust gas temper-
ature TEG_DYN_DOWN_CAT_INTER in the second part of the complete model.
The manager of the exhaust gas temperature model stores the result of the calculations in the according place
of array TEG.
Meaning of the suf?xes:
For exhaust bank speci?c variables (NC_CBK_EX_NR; TEG_MDL_CBK): "i"
For overall number of temperature models (NC_NR_TEG_MDL; TEG_MDL_INP): "t"
For number catalyst temperature models (NC_NR_CAT_MDL; CTR_CAT_MDL): "n"
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, ERU2ES, NVMRES, NVMINI, NVMSTO
Activation: operate_module_CAT_MDL: always
operate_module_CAT_MDL_ES_1S: always
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: operate_module_CAT_MDL, operate_module_CAT_MDL_ES_1S

39.10.2 Catalyst cooling at engine stop
39.10.2.1 Calculation of the catalyst temperature and exhaust gas temperature during engine off
phase
The catalyst is cooling down if the engine and also the ECU is off. There are two different calculations for the
initialization. One for a valid and one for not valid or not existing engine off time.
In both cases a factor is determined which represents the cooling down progress. If the factor is equal to "1" the
catalyst cooling down is not modeled and its temperature is equal to the last temperature stored in the non
volatile memory. If the factor is zero, TEMP_CAT is equal to the ambient temperature TAM.

39.10.4.3 Calculation of the exothermic - POW_EXO_CAT_STAT
The basic exothermic power for basis lambda (IP_LAMB_BAS_TEG) of the engine operating point without sec-
ondary air is stored in the IP_POW_EXO_CAT. This value has to be corrected for lambda values different to basis
lambda (LAMB_BAS) by the map IP_FAC_LAMB_POW_EXO_CAT and this correction can be weighted versus en-
gine operating point. Difference to basis lambda (lambda at application) is possible due to dynamic driving
conditions in comparison to calibration environment.
At PUC operation the exothermic can increase at the beginning (at transition from high load phase, where HC
and CO are also high) at then is approaching zero. Therefore the map IP_ POW_EXO_CAT_PUC can be used
for modeling of this process.

39.10.4.5 Calculation of the steady state model - TEMP_CAT
For the steady state model the same calibration data are used as in the dynamic model. During steady state
conditions the catalyst monolith temperature for the ?rst monolith TEMP_CAT_STAT is equal to the inlet steady
state temperature plus the exothermic converted into a temperature depending on mass exhaust gas ?ow and
its heat capacity.
TEG_STAT_DOWN_CAT is calculated in the same way but the heat losses are subtracted from the steady state
monolith temperature TEMP_CAT_STAT

EXTD, Catalyst exhaust gas temperature model
39.10.4.6 Dynamic model
The dynamic part of the catalyst model is again split up into following sub-functions:
- Calculation of the heat ?ows
- Calculation of the heat energy
- Dew point calculations
- Determination of the catalyst monolith temperature (?rst part)
- Determination of the outlet exhaust gas temperature (second part)
39.10.4.6.1 Calculation of the heat ?ows
The same main equations like in the "tube exhaust gas temperature model" is used for the following calcula-
tions. The only difference is that there is no factor FAC_POW_HEAT_ADD_CAT because this is assumed, that
the heat transfer coef?cient for the heat transfer between exhaust gas and catalyst monolith is so big that
the factor is "1" for all mass exhaust gas ?ows. Such factor causes that exhaust gas temperature and monolith
temperature are equal.
Additionally it is assumed that in the ?rst brick of the catalyst there are only heat gains due to exothermic
reaction and not heat losses and in the second part there are only losses.
After long PUC phases, cold exhaust gas is entering the catalyst, what is causing cooling down (negative
ADD).

ACTION_EXTD_Data2Manag(IN <PRM_HUM>, IN <PRM_LVDEW>, IN <PRM_TEGDYN>, IN <PRM_TEGSTAT>)
� General Information
The "turbine exhaust gas temperature model" is part of the complete exhaust gas temperature model.
This part models the behavior of a turbine in the exhaust line. In principle it is combination of a very easy
turbine model and a tube model. The turbine model reduces the inlet exhaust gas temperature depennding
on the turbine power POW_CBK_TEG_TUR.
Additionally there is a possibility to use this function at non turbine engine variants; the values are just not
calculated. This is due to requirement to have same software for both con?gurations, with and without turbo.
Meaning of the suf?xes:
For exhaust bank speci?c variables (NC_CBK_EX_NR; TEG_MDL_CBK): "i"
For overall number of temperature models (NC_NR_TEG_MDL; TEG_MDL_INP): "t"
For number of turbo temperature models (NC_NR_TUR_MDL; CTR_TUR_MDL): "r"

39.11.2 Engine runs to engine stop event
39.11.2.1 Calculations at ERU2ES
The variables except TEMP_TUR_STOP are initialized with "0", the TEMP_TUR_STOP is initialized with TEMP_
TUR
39.11.3 Turbine cooling at ENGINE STOP
39.11.3.1 Check if the turbine model should be calculated
The switch LC_TUR_MDL_ENA has to be set to one to calculate the turbine model otherwise the calculation is
skipped and the outlet temperature is equal to the inlet temperature. The dew point bit is automatically set to
true.
The compiler switch NC_COOL_ACT can be set to "0" or to "1". Once the switch is set to "0", the code for
calculation of the cooling down is removed, and the outputs are frozen.

EXTD, Turbine exhaust gas temperature model
39.11.3.2 Calculation cooling of the turbine temperature and exhaust gas temperature
The turbo is cooling down if the engine and also the ECU is off. There are two different calculations for the
initialization. One for a valid and one for not valid or not existing engine off time.
In both cases a factor is determined which represents the cooling down progress. If the factor is equal to "1"
the turbo cooling down is not modeled and its temperature is equal to the last temperature stored in the non
volatile memory. If the factor is zero, TEMP_TUR is equal to the ambient temperature TAM.

39.11.4 ENGINE RUNS - turbine model
The calculation of the turbine model is split up in following sections:
- Check if the turbine model should be calculated
- Calculation of the static model
- Calculation of the dynamic model
- Calculation of the dew point
39.11.4.1 Temperature loss due to turbine operating
The turbine power POW_CBK_TEG_TUR is the calculated turbine power and has to be determined by the turbo
charger functionality. The turbine inlet temperature is decreased depending on this power and depending on
the mass exhaust gas ?ow. That decreased temperature is used as input for all other calculations which are
similar to the calculations in the tube exhaust gas temperature model.

39.11.4.4.2 DYNAMIC MODEL
The dynamic part of the turbine model is again split up in seven sub-functions:
- Calculation of the temperature decrease due to the turbine
- Calculation of the heat ?ows (added and loss)
- Calculation of the heat energy added to the tube during sample time of the model
- Calculation of the exhaust gas temperature downstream the tube
- Filtering of the calculated exhaust gas temperature downstream tube
- Dew point calculations for the tube
- Determination of the temperature in/decrease of the tube wall temperature
39.11.4.4.2.1 Temperature for wall calculations
With LC_TEMP_TUR_CLC_UP_TUR=1 the calculation order can be switched. This means ?rst of all the calcula-
tions like in a tube are evaluated and afterwards this temperature is reduced by the turbine power.

39.11.4.6 Easy turbine model
39.11.4.6.1 Filtering of the input temperature
For ?ltering of the input temperature there are different correlation factors for increasing or decreasing of
the temperature. For calculation of the direction the difference between static and dynamic temperatures is
used.
The output temperature is additionally reduced by turbine power.

� Import actions:
ACTION_ERRM_GetErr(IN <PRM_IDX_ERR>, OUT <PRM_LV_ERR>)
� General Information
This module is just a template which deals with the most project needs. It is used as interface to the exhaust
gas temperature model. It creates the necessary values for the calculation of the exhaust gas temperature
model and gives the project the possibility for customer speci?c corrections of the main input values like:
Filtering of the ignition angle, engine speed, mass air ?ow, ...
Using measured lambda instead of lambda set point
Different calculation of the mass exhaust gas ?ow for projects with an unsymmetrical exhaust manifold
Additionally additive and multiplicative corrections on the engine out temperature and the catalyst exothermic
can be applied by the values:
TEG_ENG_OUT_ADD_CUS
FAC_TEG_ENG_OUT_CUS
IGA_REF_TEG_ADD_CUS
IGA_BAS_TEG_ADD_CUS
FAC_TEG_ADD_IGA_CUS
File: AE703F01.00M
11311Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

EXTD, Exhaust gas temperature model (Appl. Inc.)
POW_EXO_CAT_ADD_CUS
FAC_POW_EXO_CAT_CUS
These values can be used to add corrections for example for variable valve timing, external exhaust gas recir-
culation, bi-fuel engines or any other corrections which are necessary for the project.
For this model, the nomenclature of sizes for calculations are as below
I = NC_CBK_EX_NR, the number of exhaust cylinder banks
k = NC_CBK_IN_NR, the number of intake cylinder banks
n = NC_NR_CAT_MDL, number of catalyst exhaust gas temperature model instances
t = NC_NR_TEG_MDL, number of overall exhaust gas temperature model instances
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 100MS, 10MS

39.12.1.1 Reset
All variables are initialized with "0" except FAC_TEG_ENG_OUT_CUS, FAC_POW_EXO_CAT_CUS, LV_T_ES_TEG_
INI_NOT_VLD and FAC_MAF_INT_DEW_COR_CUS are initialized to "1".
39.12.2 Operation at 100ms
Additionally the mapping of engine speed, mass air ?ow, ignition angle, ... to the corresponding values for
calculation of the exhaust gas temperature model is de?ned.
For the calculation of the mass exhaust gas ?ow the injected fuel mass, the mass air ?ow, the secondary air
?ow and the number of exhaust banks is used.

EXTD, EXTD output selection
39.13.2.3 Generation of SAE interfaces
With C_CTR_SEL_TEMP_CAT_SAE it can be con?gured, which catalyst temperature TEMP_CAT[NC_NR_CAT_
MDL] should be provided to the Service01h PID?s of the scan tool de?ned in ISO15031-5.
C_CTR_SEL_TEMP_CAT_SAE has 4 elements regarding the 4 required SAE-interfaces (?rst element = PID3C,
2nd element = 3D, 3rd element = 3E, 4th element = 3F). Not available Catalyst temperatures are set to 0�C by
calibrating the corresponding value of C_CTR_SEL_TEMP_CAT_SAE to 0.
PID 75 shall display turbocharger temperatures.
C_CTR_SEL_TEMP_TUR_SAE has 2 elements for SAE interface, ?rst element for inlet turbine temperature and
second element for outlet turbine temperature.
Attention: Different resolution of TEMP_CAT and TEMP_CAT_xxx_SAE, TEG and TEMP_TUR_xx_SAE!

Figure 39.14.2:
39.14.2.1 TEG sensor electrical diagnosis
39.14.2.1.1 Determination of Electrical error
In case of no inhibition indicated by LV_INH_DIAG_TEG_MES_EL = 0 the electrical diagnosis is activated. LV_
CDN_DIAG_TEG_MES_EL is the opposite of the inhibition ?ag.
For the electrical diagnosis, the following symptoms are supported:
NO_SYM - no symptom
SYM_0 - shortcut to phase
SYM_1 - shortcut to ground
SYM_2 - special PWM from hardware logic
SYM_3 - period time error from hardware

Figure 39.14.4:
39.14.2.2.2 Cold Start Plausibility Diagnosis
39.14.2.2.2.1 Determination of Cold Start Plausibility Error
Counter value for cold start diagnosis CTR_CST_DIAG is incremented until it has reached the maximum limit
C_CTR_CST_DIAG_MAX.
CTR_CST_DIAG_MAX therefore de?nes the time window until the end ?ag is set
CTR_CST_DIAG_NOT_PLAUS indicates the antibouncing. Each time, the cold start plausibility is not ful?lled,
CTR_CST_DIAG_NOT_PLAUS is incremented.
For the cold start plausibility diagnosis, the following symptoms are supported:
NO_SYM - no symptom
SYM_3 - Cold Start Plausibility Error
Cold Start Plausibility Diagnosis is only determined, in case no electrical TCO or TIA error is present.

� General Information
The purpose of the diagnosis is to detect electrical faults as de?ned by OBD I requirements.
The calculation shall be done for all exhaust gas temperature sensors.
For instance, if two exhaust gas temperature sensors are considered (NC_NR_TEG_SENS = 2) then
i = 1, for exhaust gas temperature sensor 1
i = 2, for exhaust gas temperature sensor 2
otherwise (NC_NR_TEG_SENS = 1)
i = 1, for single exhaust gas temperature sensor.
� Application Conditions
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 100 ms
� Function Description
For i = 1 to NC_NR_TEG_SENS
If(1) LV_IGK = 1
and LV_CDN_DIAG_TEG_MES_EL_INTER[i] = 1
then(1)
Diagnosis : Short Circuit to Plus (SCP) and Open circuit (OC)
if(2) STATE_ERR_TEG_MES_EL_INTER[i] = 1

Else(2) LF_STATE_DGO_SCP_OC_TMP = 1 (CDN + NO_SYM ) (No symptom
present)
endif(2)
Diagnosis : Special PWM from Hardware Logic (SPC)

EXTD, Acquisition of exhaust gas temperature (gen)
39.17 Acquisition of exhaust gas temperature (gen)
� Calibration interfering function:
? Exhaust gas temperature sensors (Appl. Inc.)
? Exhaust gas temperature model
? Exhaust gas temperature sensor diag.
� Calibration ?owchart:
1. Exhaust gas temperature sensors (Appl. Inc.): Activation of the sensor acquisition
2. Exhaust gas temperature sensors: Signal conversion from pulse width to temperature and ?ltering of the
signal
3. Exhaust gas temperature sensor diag.
� Calibration process:
The calibration of IP_TEG_MES_RAW is given by the sensor caracteristic and by the external sensor control
unit. This information has to delivered by the manufacturer of the sensor control unit. With this information
(exhaust gas temperature versus pulse width) the map can be calculated.
To calibrate the map without these informations or to verify the calibartion the measured exhaust gas tem-
perature TEG_MES_RAW can be comparred with an additional external sensor. This veri?cation is allways
recommended.
All sensor show a ?ltered behavior of the real exhaust gas temperature. But its possible to get signal noise due
to bad electrical connections. To reduce this noise a ?ltering of the raw value is applied. For the calibration of
the ?ltering constant C_CRLC_TEG_MES it is important to know the ?ltering constant of the sensor. C_CRLC_
TEG_MES has to be allways bigger than the ?ltering constant of the sensor because it shoud not in?uence the
dynamic of the measured exhaust gas temperature. The only perpose of the ?ltering is to avoid not plausible
jumps.
Both calibration data can be tuned separatly for each sensor. So it?s possible to use different sensors or en-
trance wiring.

SENS]

exhaust gas temperature to suppress not plausible 
signal jumps.

EXTD, Exhaust gas temperature model (prj)
Figure 39.18.2:
The calibration constants C_CTR_SEL_XXX are used to select the value out of the output arrays of the exhaust
gas temperature model which has to be used for the speci?ed aggregate output.
In this example: The exhaust gas temperature down catalyst TEG_DYN_DOWN_CAT[1] can be selected out of
the array TEG[1...8]. With this con?guration it is equal to TEG[4] =>CTR_SEL_TEG_DOWN_CAT = 4.
� Exhaust gas temperature model (Appl. Inc.)
This module is used to modify the inputs of the exhaust gas temperature model and to calculate customer
speci?c corrections.
In this case there are two modi?cations of the model inputs:
1. LAMB_CBK_TEG_ENG and LAMB_CBK_TEG_CAT can be set to the measured lambda LAMB_LS_UP instead
of the lambda setpoint LAMB_SP therefore the switch LC_LAMB_LS_UP_ENA has to be set to one.
2. If LAMB_LS_UP is used instead of LAMB_SP the lambda would not be stable due to the lambda controller
sweeps. The catalyst exothermic reaction is strongly dependent on LAMB_CBK_TEG_CAT and would follow
these sweeps what is not the case in reality. To reduce the lambda sweeps LAMB_CBK_TEG_CAT can be
?ltered with the ?ltering constant IP_CRLC_LAMB_CBK_TEG. The ?ltering factor has to be tuned so that LAMB_
CBK_TEG_CAT is nearly stable for normal operating with active lambda controller.
The customer speci?c corrections added for the exhaust gas temperature model based on the following :
1. variable valve lift (2step VVL)
2. multiple injection (MPLH)
3. due to port ?ap (PORT)
4. due to water cooled exhaust manifold (RVC)
5. when system errors are present (SYS_ERR)
6. incase of IVVT deviation (IVVT)
7. incase of MPLH_OPP
8. Scavenging adaptations (SCAV)
For each correction the correction tables have to be tuned:
IP_TEG_ENG_OUT_COR_VVL/MPLH/MPLH_OPP/IVVT/SYS_ERR/SCAV/ PORT/ RVC/SA to correct IP_TEG_ENG_
OUT_BAS
IP_IGA_REF_TEG_COR_VVL/MPLH /MPLH_OPP/MPLH_OPP/IVVT to correct IP_IGA_REF_TEG

Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
EXTD, Exhaust gas temperature model (prj)
IP_IGA_BAS_TEG_COR_VVL/MPLH/ MPLH_OPP/ MPLH_OPP/IVVT to correct IP_IGA_BAS_TEG
IP_FAC_TEG_ADD_IGA_COR_VVL/MPLH/ MPLH_OPP/ MPLH_OPP/IVVT to correct IP_FAC_TEG_ADD_IGA
IP_POW_EXO_CAT_COR_VVL/MPLH/MPLH_OPP/SCAV to correct IP_POW_EXO_CAT
To determine theses corrections all standard maps (IP_TEG_ENG_OUT_BAS ...) have to be calibrated for high
valve lift without multiple injection (MPLH). In the next step these standard maps have to be calibrated for low
valve lift in the same way. The differences in the calibration have to be calculated and only these differences
have to be written into the correction maps for VVL. In the last step the corrections for MPLH have to be
determined. Therefore it is necessary to know whether MPLH is active only for high valve lift or low valve lift.
Like for the VVL correction the standard maps are determined with active MPLH. If MPLH is only active with
the low valve lift the correction tables for MPLH are calculated out of the difference to standard calibration
(high valve lift, no MPLH) plus the correction for low valve lift.
The calibration constant C_NR_ACK_CBK_THD_TEG_VVL is used to determine when low valve lift is acknowl-
edged. This value has to be set to a value between 1 and NC_CYL_NR/NC_CBK_IN_NR. Which value is best
has to be tested by comparing the exhaust gas temperature model behavior with the measured exhaust gas
temperature at the transition from high to low valve lift and the other way around.
The temperature correction for active scavenging is done depending on lambda and trapping ef?ciency.
For water cooled exhaust manifold system the temperature correction is done based on the actual position
of rotary valve position and temperature difference. The temperature ?ltering of can be done by correlation
factor C_CRLC_TEG_FIL_COR_RVC.
If port ?ap is used then temperature correction is done by IP_TEG_ENG_OUT_COR_PORT
To model the behaviour of catalyst temperature during PUC a high load factor is calculated depending on
the history before fuel cut off. FAC_H_LOAD_POW_EXO_CAT_PUC is input in catalyst exothermic model during
PUC. This factor is generated by the following maps:
- ID_CTR_INC_DEC_TEG_LOAD_H to increment/decrement the high-load counter
depending on MEF_KGH and TEG_UP_CAT
- ID_CTR_DEC_TEG_PUC to decrement high-load counter depending on PUC duration
- C_CTR_TEG_LOAD_H_MAX as maximum allowed value
� Dew point detection
The lambda sensor heater management needs the information that the dew point is passed which means that
no condensation water is in the exhaust system upstream the sensor. This information is provided by the dew
point ?ags LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_UP for the upstream sensor and LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_DOWN for the down stream
sensor. The following conditions are checked to set these bits:
1. Integrated mass air ?ow (MAF_KGH_INT_DEW) bigger than threshold
2. Dew point simulation of exhaust gas temperature model ended
3. Selected simulated wall temperature bigger than threshold
The ?ag is set when either condition 1. is true or condition 2. and 3. are ful?lled.
Each of these conditions is used to ensure that the dew point ?ag is not set before the measured wall temper-
ature is bigger than 70�C. As long as the exhaust gas temperature model is not well tuned the condition 2 +
3 can not be used and the threshold for condition 3 has to be set to the maximum. Therefore the integrated
mass air ?ow has to be used until the calibration of the exhaust gas temperature model is ?nished:
For the calibration of the MAF_KGH_INT threshold IP_MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_THD_LS_xx several wall temperature
sensor have to be installed especially at the valleys of the exhaust system.

Therefore the integrated
mass air ?ow has to be used until the calibration of the exhaust gas temperature model is ?nished:
For the calibration of the MAF_KGH_INT threshold IP_MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_THD_LS_xx several wall temperature
sensor have to be installed especially at the valleys of the exhaust system. These temperatures have to be mea-
sured for several engine starts with different ambient temperatures TAM and different coolant temperatures at
engine start TCO_ST. The engine has to be warmed up in idle. The threshold is determined by the measured
MAF_KGH_INT_DEW value at the moment where all wall temperatures upstream the speci?ed lambda sensor
are bigger than 70�C.
To determine the weighting versus EFF_IGA and MAF_KGH engine warm up with different catalyst heating
toque reserve and different engine operating points have to be carried out to see where the speed of MAF_
KGH_INT_DEW has to be in- or decreased.
At the next step the weighting of the thresholds IP_FAC_MAF_KGH_INT_THD_LS_XX dependent on CTR_COLD_
ST_LS_XX (number of starts without leaving the dew point phase) has to be tuned. These maps have to be

After this the calibration for the condition 1. is ?nished.
Now the exhaust gas temperature has to be tuned. Thereby it?s important that the curve of the calculated wall
temperatures at warm up is close to the lowest measured one. If this is the case the threshold for condition
3 IP_TEMP_THD_DEW_LS_XX can be set to 70�C. The map can be used to go to the safe side for very cold
conditions (low TCO_ST).
For turbo applications where normally the upstream lambda sensor is placed behind the turbine the turbine
wall temperature can be selected instead of the tube wall temperature. Therefore LC_TEMP_TUR_DEW_LS_
UP has to be set to one. With the parameters C_CTR_SEL_TUR_LS_UP, C_CTR_SEL_TUBE_LS_UP and C_CTR_
SEL_TUBE_LS_DOWN the right tube or turbine temperature for the corresponding cylinder bank have to be
selected.
Also for the condition 2 the selectors C_CTR_SEL_TEMP_DEW_MDL_LS_XX for the corresponding sensor has to
be set to the right value. Normally these are set to the same value as C_CTR_SEL_TEG_LS_XX.

C_PWM_TEG_MAX_DIAG This parameter is part of the electrical diagnosis:
The possible range for the exhaust gas temperatures converted into the corresponding
pulse width delivers the plausible range for the PWM. This parameter is set to the
maximum of the plausible PWM range.
C_PWM_TEG_MIN_DIAG This parameter is part of the electrical diagnosis:
The possible range for the exhaust gas temperatures converted into the corresponding
pulse width delivers the plausible range for the PWM. This parameter is set to the minimum
of the plausible PWM range.
C_TEG_DIF_2_DIAG This parameter is part of the diagnosis before cold start:
The temperature difference between the measured exhaust gas temperature TEG_MES
and the coolant temperature TCO before "cold start" has to be greater than this value to
detect an error. Before this value is tuned the corresponding part of "Exhaust gas
temperature sensor diag. Appl. Inc." has to be calibrated to determine the conditions for a
"cold start"
For the calibration of C_TEG_DIF_2_DIAG TEG_MES and TCO have to be comparred every
time these "cold start" conditions are full?lled. C_TEG_DIF_2_DIAG has to be set to the
maximum of the observed differences plus a certain safety offset.
C_CTR_CST_DIAG_MAX This parameter is part of the diagnosis before cold start:
It is used to have a certain statistic before the error ?ag is set. C_CTR_CST_DIAG_MAX is
equal to the number of checks (comparisons between TCO and TEG_MES) before the ?nal
diagnosis. Due to the fact that the diagnosis is calculated with a recurrence of 100ms the
value can also be seen as a time for the diagnosis. This time should not to long because
otherwise the diagnosis is not ?nished before the engine start: C_CTR_CST_DIAG_MAX
should be less than 10 to stay below 1s for the diagnosis.
C_CTR_CST_DIAG_NOT_PLAUS_MAX This parameter is part of the diagnosis before cold start:
To detect an error C_CTR_CST_DIAG_NOT_PLAUS of the C_CTR_CST_DIAG_MAX checks
have to be not plausible.
LC_CTR_COLD_ST_TEG_DIAG_INC_SWI Set this LC to 1 if the exhaust gas temperature sensor is located close to the upstream
lambda sensor. Set the LC to 0 if the exhaust gas temperature sensor is located close to
the downstream lambda sensor.
C_TEG_MES_INC + IP_T_TEG_DIAG These values have to be calibrated dependent on the activation conditions calibrated in
the Appl. Inc.. To determine C_TEG_MES_INC and IP_T_TEG_DIAG carry out different
measurements where the activation conditions for the increment diagnosis are ful?lled
(differnt TCO_ST and CTR_COLD_ST). Therefore start the engine and leave it in idle. Use the
measurement with the lowest increase of the meassured exhaust gas temperature and set
IP_T_TEG_DIAG for the corresponding TCO and CTR_COLD_ST to the
T_TEG_TEMP_INC_DIAG value at 20 seconds after reaching the the dew point. Determine
the difference between TEG_MES_MAX and TEG_MES_MIN at this point and multiply it with
0.8 to determine C_TEG_MES_INC.
Now analyse the other meassurements and determine T_TEG_TEMP_INC_DIAG where
TEG_MES_MAX-TEG_MES_MIN>C_TEG_MES/0.8.
Set IP_ T_TEG_DIAG for the corresponding TCO and CTR_COLD_ST to the determined
T_TEG_TEMP_INC_DIAG.

This image displays a block diagram, which is a common way to represent system logic, similar to how a Simulink model is structured. It's not a direct screenshot of a Simulink model, but it follows the same principles of interconnected blocks representing functions and arrows representing data flow.

## Function

The primary function of this system is comprehensive **exhaust gas temperature management, modeling, and diagnostics**. It aims to accurately estimate and monitor exhaust gas temperatures at various points (engine out, catalyst, turbine, exhaust tube), diagnose sensor health, calculate dynamic temperature limits for components (like the catalyst), and detect potential condensation (dew point). This is critical for optimizing emissions, protecting exhaust system components (especially the catalytic converter and turbocharger), and ensuring reliable vehicle operation.

## Inputs

The system receives a variety of inputs, which can be categorized into engine operating parameters and sensor measurements:

*   **Engine Operating Parameters:**
    *   **N:** Engine speed.
    *   **MAF:** Mass Air Flow (likely in g/s).
    *   **MAF_KGH:** Mass Air Flow (likely in kg/h).
    *   **LAMB_SP:** Lambda (air-fuel ratio) setpoint.
    *   **LAMB_SAWUP:** Lambda value during warm-up or specific operating conditions.
    *   **EFF_IGA_AV_CBK:** Efficiency Ignition Angle Average (Close Bank, possibly related to cylinder bank specific parameters).
    *   **TCO:** Coolant Temperature (Engine coolant outlet temperature).
    *   **TIA_THR:** Throttle Angle.
    *   **...:** Implies other engine operating parameters might be used.

*   **Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor Measurements:**
    *   **V_TEG_MES:** Voltage of the measured Exhaust Gas Temperature sensor (raw sensor output).
    *   **TEG_MES_RAW:** Raw measured Exhaust Gas Temperature (before calibration/filtering).
    *   **TEG_MES:** Measured Exhaust Gas Temperature (processed/calibrated sensor reading).

## Outputs

The system generates several outputs, providing insights into exhaust gas conditions, diagnostics, and operational limits:

*   **TEG:** Estimated Exhaust Gas Temperature (likely a comprehensive output from the manager model).
*   **LV_ERR_TEG_MES:** Level/Validity Error for Measured Exhaust Gas Temperature sensor (diagnostic flag indicating sensor fault).
*   **TEG_DYN_UP_CAT:** Dynamic Upstream Catalyst Temperature (likely a calculated limit or estimate).
*   **TEG_DYN_DOWN_CAT:** Dynamic Downstream Catalyst Temperature (likely a calculated limit or estimate).
*   **TEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL:** Dynamic Model Temperature for the Catalyst.
*   **LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_UP:** Level/Validity Temperature Dew Point Limit Upstream (e.g., indicating risk of condensation upstream).
*   **LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_DOW:** Level/Validity Temperature Dew Point Limit Downstream (e.g., indicating risk of condensation downstream).
*   **...:** Implies other related outputs may exist.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of the system can be described step-by-step:

1.  **Sensor Input and Initial Processing (IRS for TEG sensor & Exhaust gas temperature sensors):**
    *   The raw signal from the TEG (Thermogas) sensor is acquired and potentially converted/filtered by the "IRS for TEG sensor" block, yielding `TEG_MES`.
    *   The "Exhaust gas temperature sensors + (Appl. Inc.)" block takes these raw/processed sensor signals (`V_TEG_MES`, `TEG_MES_RAW`, `TEG_MES`) and makes `TEG_MES` available to other parts of the system.

2.  **Sensor Diagnosis (Exhaust gas temperature sensor diagnosis):**
    *   The `TEG_MES` signal is fed into the "Exhaust gas temperature sensor diagnosis + (Appl. Inc.)" block.
    *   This block monitors the health and plausibility of the TEG sensor, outputting `LV_ERR_TEG_MES` if a fault or invalid reading is detected. This error flag is crucial for the subsequent modeling steps to potentially switch to a substitute model or fault-tolerant operation.

3.  **Engine Parameter Pre-processing (Appl. Inc. of exhaust gas temperature model):**
    *   Various engine operating parameters (`N`, `MAF`, `MAF_KGH`, `LAMB_SP`, `LAMB_SAWUP`, `EFF_IGA_AV_CBK`, `TCO`, `TIA_THR`) are gathered here.

3.  **Engine Parameter Pre-processing (Appl. Inc. of exhaust gas temperature model):**
    *   Various engine operating parameters (`N`, `MAF`, `MAF_KGH`, `LAMB_SP`, `LAMB_SAWUP`, `EFF_IGA_AV_CBK`, `TCO`, `TIA_THR`) are gathered here.
    *   This block also receives the sensor diagnostic result (`LV_ERR_TEG_MES`).
    *   It prepares and bundles these parameters (e.g., as `N_TEG_MAF_TEG_LAMB_CBK_TEG_ENG...`) for the main temperature model. This block serves as an interface and potentially pre-calculates values relevant to the temperature models.

4.  **Exhaust Gas Temperature Modeling (Manager and Sub-models):**
    *   The "Exhaust gas temperature model (Manager)" block is the central orchestrator. It receives processed engine parameters and the measured `TEG_MES`.
    *   The Manager interacts with several specialized sub-models:
        *   **Engine out model:** Calculates the exhaust gas temperature immediately after exiting the engine cylinders.
        *   **Tube model:** Calculates temperature changes as exhaust gas flows through the pipes.
        *   **Catalyst model:** Estimates the temperature within the catalytic converter, which is crucial for its efficiency and protection.
        *   **Turbine model:** Estimates the temperature at the turbocharger's turbine (if applicable).
    *   The red arrows and the note "Result of calculations is given back by action" indicate that these sub-models perform their calculations and provide their results (e.g., estimated temperatures, heat transfer rates, or states) back to the "Manager." This suggests a model-based control or estimation strategy where the Manager integrates the sub-model results and potentially uses feedback from actual measurements (`TEG_MES`) to refine its estimates and manage the overall exhaust temperature prediction, outputting the comprehensive `TEG` estimate.

5.  **Dew Point Detection:**
    *   This block receives inputs (likely estimated temperatures, pressures, or humidity information from the Manager or pre-processor) to determine the likelihood of condensation (dew point) in the exhaust system.
    *   It outputs `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_UP` and `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_DOW`, which are indicators of dew point conditions upstream and downstream, respectively. This is important for preventing corrosion and ensuring proper function of components like sensors.

6.  **Output Selection and Delivery (EXTD output selection):**
    *   All relevant calculated values, diagnostic flags, and dynamic limits (`TEG`, `LV_ERR_TEG_MES`, `TEG_DYN_UP_CAT`, `TEG_DYN_DOWN_CAT`, `TEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL`, `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_UP`, `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_DOW`) are fed into the "EXTD output selection" block.
    *   This final stage selects, formats, and outputs the necessary information to other control units or vehicle systems, providing a complete picture of the exhaust gas temperature state and critical conditions.

## Function
This Simulink diagram describes the acquisition, processing, and output of Exhaust Gas Temperature (TEG) sensor data within an automotive system. It comprises two main parts: an initialization routine executed at system reset (Figure 39.4.2) and a recurrent operational routine that runs every 100ms (Figure 39.4.1) to continuously measure and provide TEG sensor values.

## Inputs
**For Recurrent Operation (Figure 39.4.1):**
*   **`fc_INI`**: A function call signal, triggered at system initialization (RST), which indicates the need to provide initial TEG measurement values.
*   **`fc_OPM_100MS`**: A function call signal, recurring every 100 milliseconds, which triggers the main TEG measurement processing.
*   **`ACTION_INFR_GetPwmTegSens_T3`**: An action import signal, likely representing a command or trigger to acquire PWM-based TEG sensor data, potentially from a hardware abstraction layer or sensor interface.
*   **`LV_INH_TEG_MES`**: A boolean or status signal indicating whether live TEG measurement processing should be inhibited.
*   **`NC_NR_TEG_SENS`**: A signal representing the number or identifier of the TEG sensor(s) being processed.

**For Initialization (Figure 39.4.2):**
*   **`NC_NR_TEG_SENS`**: A signal representing the number or identifier of the TEG sensor(s), used for configuring the initialization of array-like signals.

*   **`NC_NR_TEG_SENS`**: A signal representing the number or identifier of the TEG sensor(s) being processed.

**For Initialization (Figure 39.4.2):**
*   **`NC_NR_TEG_SENS`**: A signal representing the number or identifier of the TEG sensor(s), used for configuring the initialization of array-like signals.
*   *(Implicit input)*: The system reset (RST) event, which triggers this initialization function.

## Outputs
**For Recurrent Operation (Figure 39.4.1):**
*   **`PWM_TEG_MES` (1)**: The Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) value measured from the TEG sensor, likely a raw or semi-processed value.
*   **`TEG_MES_RAW` (2)**: The raw temperature measurement from the TEG sensor.
*   **`TEG_MES` (3)**: The processed or filtered temperature measurement from the TEG sensor, representing the final output value.
*   **`T_PER_TEG_MES` (4)**: The period of the TEG sensor signal.

**For Initialization (Figure 39.4.2):**
*   **`ini_teg_mes`**: A bus containing the initialized values for `PWM_TEG_MES`, `TEG_MES_RAW`, `TEG_MES`, and `T_PER_TEG_MES`. This bus is then used as the `INI_TEG_MES` input to the main operational block in Figure 39.4.1.

## Logic Flow

**Figure 39.4.2: Initialisation at RST**
1.  **Trigger:** This logic block is activated upon a system Reset (RST) event.
2.  **Default Value Assignment:** It initializes key TEG measurement signals to predefined default values:
    *   `PWM_TEG_MES` is set to 50.
    *   `TEG_MES_RAW` is set to 0.
    *   `TEG_MES` is set to 0.
    *   `T_PER_TEG_MES` is set to 100.
    The `[NC_NR_TEG_SENS]` input suggests these initializations might be applied across an array of sensors if multiple are present.
3.  **Output Bundling:** These initialized values are bundled into a bus named `ini_teg_mes`. This bus serves as the initial state for the recurrent temperature processing.

**Figure 39.4.1: Recurrent Operation (EXTD. Exhaust gas temperature sensors)**
1.  **Recurrence and Activation:** The entire block is configured to execute recurrently every 100 milliseconds (`Recurrence: 100MS`) and is always active (`Activation: always`, `Deactivation: never`).
2.  **Initialization Path:**
    *   Upon system initialization (`Init: RST`), the `fc_INI` signal is activated.
    *   This `fc_INI` signal triggers an `f()` block (`INI_TEG_MES X.1`), which effectively retrieves the `ini_teg_mes` bus (from Figure 39.4.2's logic) and passes it as `INI_TEG_MES` to the core processing block.
3.  **Core Measurement Processing (`CLC_TEG_MES X.2`):**
    *   This block, which runs every 100ms, is the central component for TEG sensor data processing.
    *   **Inputs to `CLC_TEG_MES X.2`:**
        *   `ACTION_INFR_GetPwmTegSens_T3`: An external action or data stream for PWM sensor readings.
        *   `LV_INH_TEG_MES`: A control signal that can inhibit or modify the measurement process.
        *   `NC_NR_TEG_SENS`: Sensor configuration information.
        *   `INI_TEG_MES`: The initial values for the TEG measurements, provided at system start-up.
    *   Inside this block, raw sensor data (`ACTION_INFR_GetPwmTegSens_T3`) is likely converted, filtered, and processed. The presence of `T_SIG_H_TEG` and `T_SIG_L_TEG` as internal signals suggests signal integrity checks or specific processing of high/low signal components.
4.  **Output Generation:** The `CLC_TEG_MES X.2` block outputs a structured set of TEG measurement results:
    *   `PWM_TEG_MES`: The PWM-based measurement value.
    *   `TEG_MES_RAW`: The directly measured raw temperature value.
    *   `TEG_MES`: The final, processed, and validated temperature value.

4.  **Output Generation:** The `CLC_TEG_MES X.2` block outputs a structured set of TEG measurement results:
    *   `PWM_TEG_MES`: The PWM-based measurement value.
    *   `TEG_MES_RAW`: The directly measured raw temperature value.
    *   `TEG_MES`: The final, processed, and validated temperature value.
    *   `T_PER_TEG_MES`: The computed period of the temperature signal.
    These outputs are then made available to other parts of the automotive system.

## Function
The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to process and convert raw Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) signals received from multiple exhaust gas temperature (TEG) sensors into meaningful temperature values and associated signal characteristics. It iterates through each connected TEG sensor, applying logic for measurement inhibition, characteristic line conversion, and potential signal filtering to produce accurate temperature readings.

## Inputs
The key inputs to the system, primarily driving the logic shown in Figure 39.4.4, are:

*   **`NC_NR_TEG_SENS`**: A scalar value indicating the total number of TEG sensors installed or active. This value determines the number of iterations for the FOR loop, signifying how many sensors are being processed.
*   **`LV_INH_TEG_MES`**: A boolean signal (likely an array or bus if applied on a per-sensor basis) that indicates whether the measurement for a particular TEG sensor should be inhibited or disabled.
*   **`[CTR_TEG_SENS]`**: A bus or array containing control signals, configuration parameters, or status information specific to each TEG sensor. This might include sensor type, calibration data, or error flags.

*Implicit inputs:*
The `ACTION_INFL_GetPwmTegSens` function (within the `ActionImport` block) implicitly takes raw PWM sensor data from the physical TEG sensors as its input, even though these are not explicit input ports to the diagram itself.

## Outputs
The system outputs a structured bus named `clc_sig_conv`, which aggregates processed data for all TEG sensors. This bus contains arrays, where each element corresponds to a specific sensor (indexed by `NC_NR_TEG_SENS`):

*   **`PWM_TEG_MES`**: The measured PWM value for each sensor, potentially representing the duty cycle or a normalized PWM characteristic.
*   **`TEG_MES_RAW`**: The raw temperature value derived from the PWM signal of each sensor, typically after initial characteristic line conversion but before further conditioning.
*   **`TEG_MES`**: The final, processed exhaust gas temperature value for each sensor. This likely includes filtering (e.g., low-pass filtering to reduce noise) and any other necessary signal conditioning.
*   **`T_PER_TEG_MES`**: The measured period of the PWM signal for each TEG sensor.
*   **`T_SIG_L_TEG`**: The measured low pulse duration (low time) of the PWM signal for each TEG sensor.
*   **`T_SIG_H_TEG`**: The measured high pulse duration (high time) of the PWM signal for each TEG sensor.

## Logic Flow

The core logic flow is implemented within a FOR loop, as detailed in Figure 39.4.4, and iterates `NC_NR_TEG_SENS` times (once for each TEG sensor).

1.  **Loop Initialization**: The process begins with a `For Iterator Subsystem` (labeled `for (NC_NR_TEG_SENS=i)`), which iterates `NC_NR_TEG_SENS` times. For each iteration `i`, the logic inside the loop processes the data corresponding to the `i`-th TEG sensor.

2.  **Measurement Inhibition Check**:
    *   For the current sensor `i`, its `LV_INH_TEG_MES` signal (if arrayed) is selected and then inverted by a `NOT` block. This effectively determines if the measurement for the current sensor is *not* inhibited.
    *   This "not inhibited" status, along with relevant `CTR_TEG_SENS` for sensor `i`, feeds into an `If` block (`cond_if`). This `If` block acts as a conditional gate, enabling or disabling the subsequent measurement and conversion steps for the current sensor based on the inhibition status and other control signals.

3.  **Raw PWM Signal Acquisition (`ACTION_INFL_GetPwmTegSens`)**:

## Function
This Simulink diagram describes a system for processing and conditioning Exhaust Gas Temperature (TEG) sensor signals. Its primary function is to convert raw sensor measurements (both high/low signals and a Pulse Width Modulation - PWM - signal) into a linearized, filtered, and compensated exhaust gas temperature value. It also provides raw temperature and derived/measured PWM signals for further use or diagnostics.

## Inputs
1.  **T_SIG_H_TEG_i**: High signal from the TEG sensor. This likely represents one part of a ratiometric or differential sensor output.
2.  **T_SIG_L_TEG_i**: Low signal from the TEG sensor. This likely represents the other part of a ratiometric or differential sensor output, combined with the high signal to derive a reading.
3.  **CTR_TEG_SENS**: Controller signal for the TEG sensor. This input seems to control lookup table selection (`idx_k`) and filter characteristics (`IV`), suggesting it selects operating modes or sensor types.
4.  **[PWM_TEG_MES_i]**: The raw measured Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) signal from the TEG sensor. This is the primary input used for temperature conversion via a lookup table.
5.  **C_CRLC_TEG_MES**: A calibration constant used to configure the digital low-pass filter for temperature measurement.

## Outputs
1.  **PWM_TEG_MES_i** (Output port 1): A calculated PWM value derived from the `T_SIG_H_TEG_i` and `T_SIG_L_TEG_i` inputs. This might be used for internal diagnostics, plausibility checks, or as an alternative representation of the sensor state.

4.  **T_PER_TEG_MES_i** (Output port 4): Likely represents the period measurement of the input PWM signal from the TEG sensor.

## Function

The primary function of this module is to determine and output the acquisition inhibition status for each exhaust gas temperature (TEG) sensor. It calculates a flag for each sensor, indicating whether its data acquisition should be inhibited, based on existing error conditions and pre-configured calibration settings.

## Inputs

1.  **LV_ERR_TEG_MES [NC_NR_TEG_SENS]:** A vector of error flags, where each element corresponds to an individual exhaust gas temperature sensor, indicating if an error is present for that sensor.
2.  **NC_NR_TEG_SENS:** A scalar value representing the total number of exhaust gas temperature sensors in the system. This value determines the dimension of the `LV_ERR_TEG_MES` and `LC_TEG_MES_INH` vectors.
3.  **LC_TEG_MES_INH [NC_NR_TEG_SENS]:** A vector of calibration flags. Each element corresponds to a TEG sensor, indicating if its acquisition is to be inhibited based on calibration settings.
4.  **fc_INI:** An internal initialization trigger signal.
5.  **fc_OPM_10MS:** An internal operational trigger signal, indicating the module's 10ms recurrence cycle.

## Outputs

1.  **LV_INH_TEG_MES [NC_NR_TEG_SENS]:** A vector of flags, where each element indicates whether the acquisition of the corresponding exhaust gas temperature sensor is inhibited. This is the main output of the function.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of the diagram can be described step-by-step:

1.  **Scheduling and Activation:** The module is scheduled to execute periodically every 10 milliseconds (`Recurrence: 10MS`). It is always active (`Activation: always`) and never deactivated.
2.  **Initialization Phase (INI X.1):** Upon system initialization (triggered by `Init: RST` leading to `fc_INI`), an initialization block (`INI X.1`) is activated. This block performs any necessary setup or reset of internal states or parameters, producing an `ini` signal. This `ini` signal is then passed to the main operational logic block (`OPM X.2`) to prepare it for operation.
3.  **Operational Trigger (OPM X.2):** Every 10 milliseconds, the `fc_OPM_10MS` signal triggers the execution of the main operational logic block (`OPM X.2`).
4.  **Input Acquisition:** The `OPM X.2` block receives the following critical inputs:
    *   The `LV_ERR_TEG_MES` vector, containing error flags for each sensor.
    *   The `NC_NR_TEG_SENS` scalar, defining the number of sensors.
    *   The `LC_TEG_MES_INH` vector, containing calibration-based inhibit flags for each sensor.
    *   The `ini` signal from the initialization phase, providing context or initial values for the operational logic.
5.  **Core Logic Execution:** Inside the `OPM X.2` block, a function `f()` is executed. This function performs the core logic for determining the inhibition status. It is highly probable that for each sensor, the `f()` function performs a logical OR operation: if a sensor has an error (`LV_ERR_TEG_MES` is true) OR if its acquisition is calibrated to be inhibited (`LC_TEG_MES_INH` is true), then its corresponding output inhibit flag should be set. This logic is applied across all `NC_NR_TEG_SENS` sensors.
6.  **Output Generation and Transmission:** The result of the `f()` function, represented by the `opm` signal, directly forms the `LV_INH_TEG_MES` vector. This vector, containing the final acquisition inhibition flags for all TEG sensors, is then outputted from the module for use by other parts of the automotive system.

## Function
The primary function of this system is to accurately estimate and manage exhaust gas temperatures at various points within the exhaust system. It achieves this by combining real-time sensor measurements, steady-state model predictions, and dynamic component model predictions. The system provides robust temperature estimates even in cases of sensor failure by falling back to model-based values, and it tracks the internal temperatures of key exhaust components.

## Inputs
*   **Sensor Acquisition (TEG_MES):** Raw exhaust gas temperature measurements from multiple sensors.
*   **Engine Out Temperature (TCO):** An estimated or measured temperature at the engine outlet, serving as the initial upstream temperature.
*   **LC_TEG_MDL_SENS_ENA / NC_NR_TEG_SENS:** Control flags indicating the availability and validity (absence of error) of exhaust gas temperature sensors.
*   **Engine Operating Conditions:** Implicit inputs to the Steady State model and Dynamic models (e.g., engine speed, load, air mass flow) that influence exhaust gas temperatures. These are not explicitly shown but are fundamental for such models.
*   **T_ES:** Engine off duration time, used for calculating the cooling-down factor during initialization of component temperatures.
*   **HUM_EX_GAS_MDL, LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL:** Humidity of exhaust gas model and dewpoint flags/model (initialized to zero, implying they might be inputs for more complex models not fully detailed here).

## Outputs
*   **TEG_STAT_MDL[x]:** An array of estimated steady-state exhaust gas temperatures at five different points in the exhaust system (x=1 to 5).
*   **TEG_DYN_MDL[x]:** An array of estimated dynamic exhaust gas temperatures at five different points in the exhaust system (x=1 to 5).
*   **TEG[x]:** The final, managed, and robust exhaust gas temperature output for each of the five points (x=1 to 5), which serves as an input for subsequent downstream models or control functions.
*   **TEMP_TUBE_1:** Modeled temperature of the wall of the first exhaust tube.
*   **TEMP_TUR_1:** Modeled temperature of the turbine housing.
*   **TEMP_TUBE_2:** Modeled temperature of the wall of the second exhaust tube.
*   **TEMP_CAT_1:** Modeled temperature of the catalyst monolith.

## Logic Flow

The system operates on parallel steady-state and dynamic modeling paths, integrated by a central manager.

1.  **Sensor Acquisition:**
    *   Raw exhaust gas temperatures are acquired from various sensors positioned along the exhaust stream. These sensor readings (`TEG_MES`) are fed to the "Manager of the exhaust gas temperature model".

2.  **Steady State Model:**
    *   This section generates steady-state temperature estimates (`TEG_STAT_MDL[x]`) for five distinct points in the exhaust system.
    *   `TEG_STAT_MDL[1]` likely represents the engine-out steady-state temperature, possibly derived from an "Engine out temperature model".
    *   Subsequent steady-state temperatures (`TEG_STAT_MDL[2]` to `TEG_STAT_MDL[5]`) are calculated for different locations (e.g., before turbo, after turbo, before catalyst, after catalyst) based on engine operating conditions and pre-calibrated maps.

3.  **Dynamic Model:**
    *   This section comprises several individual component models: "Tube model 1", "Turbo model 1", "Tube model 2", and "Cat model 1".
    *   **Engine Out Temperature Model:** Provides the initial dynamic temperature `TEG_DYN_MDL[1]`.
    *   **Component Models:** Each component model receives upstream dynamic temperature inputs and produces:
        *   A dynamic exhaust gas temperature estimate at its outlet (`TEG_DYN_MDL[x]`).
        *   Its own internal component temperature (`TEMP_TUBE_1`, `TEMP_TUR_1`, `TEMP_TUBE_2`, `TEMP_CAT_1`). These component temperatures are crucial for modeling the thermal inertia and heat exchange within the exhaust system components.
    *   The dynamic models account for transient thermal behavior (heating/cooling rates, heat capacity) based on exhaust gas flow, temperature, and component specific parameters.

4.  **Manager of the Exhaust Gas Temperature Model:**
    *   This central block receives all `TEG_STAT_MDL[x]`, `TEG_DYN_MDL[x]`, and the sensor acquisition data.

*   The dynamic models account for transient thermal behavior (heating/cooling rates, heat capacity) based on exhaust gas flow, temperature, and component specific parameters.

4.  **Manager of the Exhaust Gas Temperature Model:**
    *   This central block receives all `TEG_STAT_MDL[x]`, `TEG_DYN_MDL[x]`, and the sensor acquisition data.
    *   For each point `i` (from 1 to 5), it determines the final output `TEG[i]` based on the following logic:
        *   If a sensor value (`TEG_MES` for point `i`) is available *and* no sensor error is detected (i.e., `LC_TEG_MDL_SENS_ENA[NC_NR_TEG_SENS]` is true/1 for that sensor), then `TEG[i]` is set to the measured value (`TEG_MES`).
        *   If an error is detected *or* no sensor is available (i.e., `LC_TEG_MDL_SENS_ENA[NC_NR_TEG_SENS]` is false/0), then `TEG[i]` is set to the dynamic model output `TEG_DYN_MDL[i]`.
    *   This logic prioritizes sensor data when available and reliable, falling back to the dynamic model for robustness.

5.  **Initialization:**
    *   **Component Temperatures:** At initialization, the dynamic exhaust gas temperatures (`TEG_DYN_MDL`) are initialized based on the component temperature *upstream* of their position. The component temperatures themselves (e.g., `TEMP_TUBE_1`, `TEMP_TUR_1`) are initialized using a stored temperature from the last engine shutdown, adjusted by a cooling-down factor that depends on the engine off duration time (`T_ES`).
    *   **Specific Initialization Rules:**
        *   `TEG[1]` and `TEG_DYN_MDL[1]` are initialized with `TCO` (Engine Out Temperature).
        *   `TEG[2]` and `TEG_DYN_MDL[2]` are initialized with `TEMP_TUBE[1]`.
        *   `TEG[3]` and `TEG_DYN_MDL[3]` are initialized with `TEMP_TUR[1]`.
        *   `TEG[4]` and `TEG_DYN_MDL[4]` are initialized with `TEMP_TUBE[2]`.
        *   `TEG[5]` and `TEG_DYN_MDL[5]` are initialized with `TEMP_CAT[1]`.
    *   **Other Initializations:** Steady-state temperatures (`TEG_STAT_MDL`), exhaust gas humidities (`HUM_EX_GAS_MDL`), and dewpoint flags (`LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL`) are initialized to zero.

This architecture ensures a resilient and accurate estimation of exhaust gas temperatures, crucial for functions like engine control, emissions management, and component protection.

## Function
This Stateflow chart, named `Chart_SCHEDULER`, serves as a centralized scheduler and dispatcher for various sub-models pertaining to Exhaust Gas Temperature (EGT) modeling, as indicated by the "EXTD: Exhaust gas temperature model" title. Its primary function is to:

2.  **Iterate through configured EGT models**: Process each model in a defined sequence.
3.  **Schedule model execution**: Run specific models only when their configured sample offsets match a system modulo result, allowing for varied execution rates.
4.  **Dispatch to model-specific logic**: Based on the model type, call the appropriate sub-module (e.g., Engine Out, Tube, Catalyst, Turbine).
5.  **Process model outputs**: Store sampled temperatures and update measurement values, incorporating either dynamic model calculations or sensor readings based on specific conditions.

## Logic Flow
The chart's logic flow describes the sequential and conditional execution for scheduling and operating the EGT models:

1.  **Entry and Global Sampling Control**:

2.  **Model Iteration and Scheduling**:

3.  **Model Parameter Loading**:

5.  **Measurement Value Update**:

## 39.7.2.3.4.1 Calculation of Flag indicating that dew point is passed at lambda sensor

### Function
This Simulink diagram calculates two boolean flags, `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_EXT_k` and `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_TMP_i_k`, which indicate whether a dew point condition has been detected or passed at the lambda sensor. This logic is crucial for controlling the lambda sensor's heating or activation strategies to prevent damage or ensure accurate operation during cold start conditions.

### Inputs
*   `C_FAC_MAF_INT_DEW_COR_CUS_k`: Constant/Parameter for MAF Integral Dewpoint Correction Factor (Customer specific).
*   `MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_THD_k`: Parameter for MAF Integral Dewpoint Threshold.
*   `MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_k`: Actual signal for MAF Integral Dewpoint.
*   `LV_ACT_EOL_k`: Boolean flag indicating if the Lambda Sensor is Active End Of Life.
*   `LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL_MAF_INT_k`: Boolean flag from the modelled dewpoint temperature based on MAF Integral.
*   `LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL_CST_TMP_k`: Boolean flag from the modelled dewpoint temperature based on Coolant Temperature.
*   `LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL_TMP_k`: Boolean flag from the general modelled dewpoint temperature.
*   `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_RST_k`: Boolean flag indicating if the Lambda Sensor Dewpoint Reset is active.
*   `T_AST_DC`: Signal for AST (After Start Temperature) after Dewpoint Calculation.
*   `C_T_AST_MIN_DEW_LS`: Constant/Parameter for Minimum AST Temperature required for dewpoint detection at the Lambda Sensor.
*   `LV_TEMP_DEW_CH_INT_k`: Boolean flag for Dewpoint Temperature Channel Integral.

### Outputs
*   `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_EXT_k`: Boolean flag indicating if the dew point is passed at the Lambda Sensor (External condition).
*   `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_TMP_i_k`: Boolean flag indicating if the dew point is passed at the Lambda Sensor (Temporary internal condition).

### Logic Flow

1.  **Calculate `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_EXT_k`:**
    *   An adjusted MAF integral dewpoint threshold is calculated by multiplying `C_FAC_MAF_INT_DEW_COR_CUS_k` with `MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_THD_k` (Multiplication block V.7.3).
    *   This adjusted threshold is then compared against `MAF_KGH_INT_DEW_k` using a "less than or equal to" operator (V.6.5). This results in a boolean `Condition_A`.
    *   `Condition_A` is combined with the `LV_ACT_EOL_k` flag using an AND gate (V.6.6).
    *   The output of this AND gate directly sets the `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_EXT_k` flag.

2.  **Calculate `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_TMP_i_k` (Part 1 - Top branch):**
    *   The flags `LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL_MAF_INT_k` and `LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL_CST_TMP_k` are combined using an OR gate (V.6.2). This forms a boolean `Condition_B`.

3.  **Calculate `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_TMP_i_k` (Part 2 - Middle branch):**
    *   The `LV_TEMP_DEW_MDL_TMP_k` flag is taken as is, forming a boolean `Condition_C`.

4.  **Calculate `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_TMP_i_k` (Part 3 - Bottom branch):**
    *   The `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_RST_k` flag is inverted using a NOT gate (V.6.3), meaning the reset is *not* active. This forms a boolean `Condition_D`.
    *   The `T_AST_DC` signal is compared to the `C_T_AST_MIN_DEW_LS` constant using a "greater than or equal to" operator (V.6.0). This forms a boolean `Condition_E`.
    *   `Condition_D` and `Condition_E` are combined using an AND gate (V.6.6).

This forms a boolean `Condition_D`.
    *   The `T_AST_DC` signal is compared to the `C_T_AST_MIN_DEW_LS` constant using a "greater than or equal to" operator (V.6.0). This forms a boolean `Condition_E`.
    *   `Condition_D` and `Condition_E` are combined using an AND gate (V.6.6). This means the reset is inactive AND the AST temperature is above the minimum. This forms `Result_AND_2`.

5.  **Final Calculation for `LV_TEMP_DEW_LS_TMP_i_k`:**
